recipientOrganization.description: Detached youth and community project working with families and young people marginalised through social / economic factors. NOMAD youth worker works with young people (13-18 range), community worker works with families with pre school children/ teens. We support vulnerable and disadvantaged children, young people and families who are isolated through economic and/or complex social issues. We organise a deliver a range of activities and programmes including football projects, Life skills programmes, one to one mentoring, Healthy Life Style Projects, One to One and Group Parenting programmes, advice and guidance on benefits, housing and employment particularly for NEETS, support and signposting for those abusing drugs/alcohol, Family Focus support Sessions for parents and young people working through the issues together and community events including Day Trips and Family Fun Times in local parks or streets. Working in close partnership/liaison with other agencies including police, health & social care, Town Council and schools etc we aim to support people in making positive life choices, encouraging them to be actively involved in their local community, reducing anti social behaviour, improving family relationships and having

recipientOrganization.description: As a community enterprise, Bright Sparks Science aims to make STEM subjects assessable to all children, whatever their age, ability or background, by providing educational and entertaining science based activities to primary school children across the Oxfordshire area. We want to inspire children’s interest in science and technology from an early age, in the hope that they will pursue a STEM related career, which is key to the growth and development of Oxordshire's future. Many schools in the area have already benefited from our hands-on science activities this academic year, through school assemblies, workshops and after school clubs funded by parents. However, we want to be able to reach those children from deprived backgrounds and get the chance to inspire them in the same way.

recipientOrganization.description: The Oxfordshire Book Award is an award voted for entirely by children, who read and nominate their favourite books. The award has three categories: Best Book (Secondary School Category), Best Book (Primary School Category), Best Picture Book (Primary School Category). Children throughout Oxfordshire can take part either at participating primary and secondary schools, or through any public library. The aim of OBA is to encourage the participation of children and young people, both in participating schools and in the Oxfordshire community, in reading more widely,to promote books that will inspire and develop readers for life and to encourage lively debate, discussion and critical appreciation of books. The committee help schools by providing copies of the nominated books, organise and fund a fun awards event attended by guest speakers and help some schools with transportation costs to this events.

recipientOrganization.description: Wroxton Village Hall has been used by the community since 1935 and is now managed by five Trustees whose aim is provide a warm and attractive, up to date amenity for Villagers and the local community. The Trustees organise a variety of traditional village events to attract as many local people to the hall as possible, such as a monthly film night in conjunction with Age Concern, a twice yearly flea market, Beetle Drives and Bingo events for families, a Christmas Fair, Saturday morning Farmer's Market, a yearly Flower and Produce Show. An art exhibition is planned for spring 2014. The hall is also used by village organisations such as the Gardening Club, the local Church, Sports Club, Parish Council, Village School to hold social events and meetings and is rented by individuals, both residents of Wroxton and others, for private functions. The car park and hall furniture are also rented out from time to time.

recipientOrganization.description: The Oxford Food Bank collects fresh food that would otherwise be thrown away, from wholesalers and supermarkets. It delivers the food to about 50 charities in and around Oxford that help the homeless, the elderly, people with mental health problems, children, and other vulnerable members of the community. Our deliveries provide fresh fruit, vegetables, bread and dairy produce seven days a week. Any left over food is bagged up and delivered to five organisations that provide food to individuals. The food bank keeps between three and five tonnes of food out of the waste stream every week, and supplements about 7000 meals per week.

recipientOrganization.description: Rose Hill Junior Youth Club offers children aged 6 -12 years, living in Rose Hill (RH) the chance to engage in safe, meaningful, creative and healthy activities. The organisation of the club is overseen and monitored by a volunteer management committee made up of local parents and residents, staff and local Councillors. The twice weekly club sessions are staffed by qualified play workers and supported by Oxfordshire Play Association. Launched in March 2011 the JYC supports up to 95 children each week at two club sessions. It is a totally inclusive club offering a wide range of activities for children aged 6 – 12 years. There is a nominal charge of 50p per child per session. This fee is waived if a parent is unable to afford the subscription. We offer specialist support to children with ADHD, Autism and Special Educational Needs (SEN) . Over 30% of children attending have some form of additional need. Many children in Rose Hill have challenging lives which impact on their behaviour. The therapeutic nature of play is crucial to their social, emotional and behavioural development. JYC offers children the opportunity to do things THEIR way, giving them autonomy, promoting self expression, allowing them to develop confidence, self worth, creativity and resilience. Often a stark contrast to life within school and home. JYC offers these children a structure of support and a choice of activities. When their needs are met (fun, societal, good food, positive reinforcement, independent choice) their behaviour improves considerably, they work through their challenges using play and spending time with trusted adults. For the majority of children attending, JYC is the only facilitated play opportunity in their lives. For the children not attending JYC, it is likely that there is none. The club also offers: ? A Young Leaders (YLs) programme for older children where: * YLs support and mentor younger ones, learn positive behaviour, social skills and self worth and support staff in chosen activities or run them independently ? A volunteering and training programme: *JYC offers support and training to local people wishing to gain experience working with children ? A healthy eating and cooking project: *children prepare, cook and serve a hot healthy tea at every session, lead by qualified nutritionist and kitchen team Our aims and objectives are: To give a child a sense of their own worth and capability To create a nurturing, safe and creative atmosphere To encourage positive language, social skills and communication To give enjoyment and respite from a child’s pressured and often traumatic life To provide an opportunity to engage in different kinds of innovative projects To work with children to raise their self esteem, self confidence and independence through creative activities To celebrate their success and encourage pride in their achievements
recipientOrganization.name: Rose Hill Junior Youth Club

recipientOrganization.description: Tandem in Oxford provides one to one befriending partnerships between volunteers and adults with mental distress. We aim to make a lasting difference to people’s lives, not simply to alleviate a symptom or current problem. We encourage people who have suffered from mental distress such as depression, anxiety or schizophrenia, by linking them with volunteers and enabling supportive relationships to develop. Our volunteer befrienders are trained in understanding mental health issues and are there to encourage people to regain and develop their self-confidence. They enable people to take part in activities in their community, quietly and unobtrusively – just like anyone else. We also offer a weekly Social Group for those waiting for befriending partnerships. This was initially offered as a way of addressing the growing waiting list. The group’s friendly and informal demeanour has been very successful in encouraging reluctant individuals to participate.
recipientOrganization.name: Tandem in Oxfordshire

recipientOrganization.description: “Yellow Submarine Holidays” provides supported holidays and activities for people with learning disabilities (PWLD). It operates with three aims: 1/ to offer PWLD choice in holiday options and day-trips at affordable (/subsidised) prices; 2/ to provide respite for those who care for PWLD; 3/ to give young people training and volunteering opportunities to support this vulnerable group on our outings both for the immediate gain of assisting positively and so they are better equipped to promote community cohesion. In 2009, Yellow Submarine partnered with two day centres and a local authority and four holidays with 19 PWLD (and their carers who gained respite) benefitting. The trips that have taken place so far have been very popular and successful both with the ‘service users’, their carers and the volunteers who helped. Video feedback can be viewed on our site, with carers saying the holidays have helped increase confidence, create new friendships, and give a welcome break! Yellow Submarine believes people with learning disabilities deserve to live life to the full. We are a small award-winning charity which prides itself on giving some of the most disadvantaged people in Oxfordshire confidence, independence and a sense of self-worth. For children (aged 11-18) living in Oxfordshire we run an extensive programme in the school holidays. For adults (18+) we run residential holidays, work experience & training and a weekly social club. Case study published on website Nov 2014, original stored here: Y:\NEW FILESTORE 2011\7 MARKETING, COMMS & CAMPAIGNS\CASE STUDIES\Grant stories

recipientOrganization.description: We are a very small charity employing three part time members of staff. However, with our supportive volunteer base (currently 92 volunteers) we are able to provide much needed support to people who are affected by loneliness and in doing so we help to improve their physical and mental health. Weekly we provide a range of social and therapeutic activities for over 150 older people who’s financial, physical and mental well-being are affected by the impact of loneliness. We work to address the complex problems by providing: (a) opportunities for people to come together in a social environment, (b) weekly therapeutic activities, (c) a befriending service for those who are to frail or housebound or lack the confidence to engage with our support group activities (d) a wide range of volunteering opportunities that enable services users to engage at a level of their choice and capacity. We also provide a volunteer car scheme to ensure that anyone who is lonely can access our services.
recipientOrganization.name: Archway Foundation

recipientOrganization.description: Oxford Hub is a student-led network with a membership of over 6,500 students and 35 student societies and volunteering projects at the University of Oxford. We believe that university students have the power and potential to shape a better world. We know that the current challenges faced by local and global communities – from climate change to educational disadvantage to an ageing population – can only be solved by engaging the students of today, the leaders of tomorrow, with these pressing social issues and equipping them with the skills to solve them. We: - inspire students about social issues each year through conferences and speaker events on social issues; - connect students to opportunities to make a difference in their local communities - in local schools, care homes and food banks; - support students to set up their own charitable projects through our social leadership activities. Oxford Hub is part of Student Hubs, a national charity.

recipientOrganization.description: Home-Start Oxford provides volunteer support in the family home to vulnerable families on a weekly basis. All the families we work with have at least one child under 5, are often socially isolated and many have complex needs including disability, physical or psychological illness, abuse- or refugee-related problems and/or housing/financial issues. To do this, we employ 3 coordinators who recruit train and then supervise volunteers who undergo a 10 week preparation course which covers parenting, child development, safeguarding, confidentiality, and family welfare matters. They are then matched with families by our coordinators who assess and oversee the support for both families and volunteers. Some of our volunteers have moved into work, or started careers in related employment as a result. We also employ a part-time family support worker to work with families needing immediate and more focused help, and a part-time administrator.
recipientOrganization.name: Home-Start Oxford

recipientOrganization.description: The Ley Community’s rehabilitation recovery programme is an abstinence based therapeutic community model of intervention which utilises peer support and self-help in its intensive and highly structured residential rehabilitation programme. The programme is targeted at people with addiction to drugs and/or alcohol; including prolific offenders with an addictions history and individuals with a short history of substance misuse. The recovery programme is unique because we use Therapeutic Community (TC) Concepts linked to recovery outcomes together with a range of other therapeutic interventions. It is our aim through these programmes for clients to complete the programme and secure full-time employment, move out into independent living and no longer be ‘in treatment’. The intensive structured approach provides residents with an abstinence based pathway to recovery and re-engagement within mainstream society as contributing citizens.
recipientOrganization.name: Ley Community

recipientOrganization.description: Farm Ability is a unique and innovative project supporting adults across Oxfordshire with autism and/or learning disabilities to become 'co- farmers' on the farm, where they learn how to care for animals, countryside and horticultural skills and how to prepare healthy food. We value the positive health benefits from working with animals and nature, and are passionate about removing some of the barriers to physical exercise and accessing the outdoors which many adults with learning disabilities face. Our co-farmers spend most of the day in the fresh air engaging in a range of meaningful activities, including: collecting and grading eggs, feeding farm animals, working in an organic garden, tree planting and preparing food with fresh farm produce. The project provides a hands-on programme of training, equipping participants with real world skills to transition into work and live more independently. Through this, they learn that they 'can do', raising confidence and ultimately achievement.
recipientOrganization.name: Farm Ability

recipientOrganization.description: We are the only food bank in the city that provides food directly to individuals. We have identified children and families as our primary target customers. Typically our customers have three or four children and the family has made contact with one or more social service agencies in the previous 12 months. In addition to families, we also have a large number of singles, mainly men, referred through the probation services. In the context of a drop-in café, we provide three days' nutritionally balanced, non-perishable, emergency food aid for people in crisis, identified and referred by front-line voucher distributors: GPs, social workers,health visitors, the CAB, clergy, community workers, police, probation officers, teachers and any professionals who are likely to come into contact with people in real need. We try to make time for everyone who comes through our door and so some volunteers chat to people over a hot drink and a snack while others pack their food parcels.
recipientOrganization.name: Community Emergency Foodbank (CEF)

recipientOrganization.description: The Cutteslowe Seniors are the only established and mutually supportive group for the over 65s, who live in (or have close connections with) the Cutteslowe estate. The majority of Seniors are over 75 years of age, including a couple members of over 90 years of age and a significant number are infirm and/or live on their own. A bimonthly programme of speakers, activities and trips to places of interest is organised. The subsidised cost and special transport arrangements ensure that no one is discriminated against due to lack of financial resources or physical disability. Another aim is to form a link with the young people of Cutteslowe and to this end an Intergenerational Project has been set up. The pupils of Cutteslowe Primary School meet with the Seniors and ask questions about their experiences of the War, their school days etc. Sessions are recorded and the aim is to produce an educational pack.Meeting their friends every two weeks is of great benefit to Seniors.
recipientOrganization.name: Cutteslowe Seniors Group

recipientOrganization.description: Grove Challengers Football Club was formed in 1971 by Ruth O’Hanlon after getting fed up of her son and his friends playing football in her garden. Since then, the club has grown considerably with over 210 children registered. Her principle of providing a safe, secure environment for children to play football still remains the club’s core value. We have 12 teams which start with our raising stars, or under 6s, all the way up to under 15s. We have also recently started 2 new girls’ teams.We support the local community by providing a club for the children to come and play football. This ensures the young children have a place to go, to not only develop their footballing skills, but also improves discipline, health, general well-being and most importantly, they make friends and have lots of fun!! By supporting our club with this grant, it means we can continue to keep our subscriptions low and so ensure the children can still come and play.

recipientOrganization.description: To support members of the Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender (LGBT) community in Oxfordshire. Despite the very welcome changes in legislation which have have given well needed protection and rights to LGBT people, there are still many who feel adversely affected by their sexuality or gender identity, including those who still feel concerned about coming out at work, those who feel guilty due to religious beliefs or cultural norms, those seeking asylum from overseas who are fleeing persecution or even the death penalty, the young who are still bullied in school and those LGBT people living in rural areas who feel very isolated. Our aim is to give a professional support service to these people via phone, email or face to face interactions with our band of dedicated and very well trained volunteers, to help our clients find a solution to solution to their issues and problems.

We aim to bring the elderly and in many cases, the less mobile, out of their homes and into a friendly and invigorating environment where they can make and meet friends and enjoy each others company. We are very much aware that some of the members do not always receive a good and balanced diet so wherever possible we aim to provide refreshments and nourishing meals. recipientOrganization.description: Full Circle aims to build positive relationships between younger and older people in Oxfordshire. Through fun and friendship in a supportive environment, Full Circle nurtures respect and understanding between generations. Our purpose is two-fold - to support the advancement of education of school age children and to support the relief of older people across Oxfordshire and beyond. Through the provision of weekly intergenerational groups, primarily within schools, we provide opportunities to share knowledge, skills and experiences across the generations. Our work provides opportunities to meet new people of all ages and backgrounds helping older people to combat loneliness and isolation which directly impacts health and well-being and supporting younger people with emotional development needs. By involving schools, we have a sustainable model which allows us to fund and manage the Full Circle groups for a short period of time before handing over group ownership to the schools.

The villages are isolated communities with few facilities and transport links. The eldest member was born in 1924 and the majority are in their 70s and 80s. Many have mobility constraints and live alone. The Club is 50 strong at present and activities take place monthly. The activities are based on engagement and encouraging activities which help to maintain independence, provide mental stimulation and physical activities. This includes organized trips or events in Fritwell Village Hall. The Club is managed by a Committee of seven all of whom are volunteers. We promote community cohesion and and have a number of activities ( Skating, Fun Run ) and projects to engage the young people. We are also now planning to start a under 10s Football team for the village as currently our young people go to Bicester for this. recipientOrganization.description: Aims of the Project: *Promote community cohesion and integration through bringing together the diverse communities of Oxford to design, manage and deliver the annual Oxford Summer Mela *Promote community cohesion & integration by using the Mela project as a template for future joint community activity by the communities of Oxford (in partnership with main stream agencies, City Council, County Council, Educational providers, Health & well being providers etc) *Build and share skills to create a sense of joint achievement and improve opportunities for learning which build on joint understanding. OHTCCP wants to organise events to bring the diverse Communities of Oxford together and to ensure that our gatherings are a testimony to our focus on inclusivity, ethnicity and faith, gender, age and multi-generation families around Oxfordshire. The Mela, besides providing entertainment, allows people to meet other organisations (statutory & voluntary) and have access to the services they provide. Every year OHTCCP also organise two other community-wide cultural events - Celebration of the Spring Festival of Holi and a Diwali Dinner Dance in the autumn. We have 5 teams (the Chippy Trixsters) of different ages, with developing teams to competitive teams, with the aspiration to aim high in their level of field, with the support of our coaches who work hard to build these skills. We then offer one-to-one counselling, or group counselling (Bereavement Support Groups) or Friendship Groups; if appropriate, we refer people to other organisations, both voluntary and statutory. recipientOrganization.description: We are an adventure Playground with halls and outside space providing recreational play for 8-13 year old children. We run an after school club that is mainly attended by children at the local junior schools and various play schemes during school holidays when children come from further afield and include those from secondary schools. Our aim is to provide these children and young people with a safe place where they can learn to interact with others and accept those who are different from themselves as they use all our facilities.The obesity rate at the end of primary schools in Blackbird Leys is 29% yet here at the playground they are able to exercise by having fun. We also aim to provide them, during the after school club with a healthy snack. They play on the structures and have endless fun as they run round often playing imaginary games. A new in-ground trampoline has added to the choice of equipment they can use. Our staff and volunteers are trained in play principles and these encourage children to choose their own activities so that the child can make a choice that fits their mood. One of our objectives is to allow the children who come to be able to find constructive ways of coping with the different feelings they might have. They use the arts and crafts facilities, many table games such as table tennis, table football and pool and will cook and garden as well as use the many outside play structures and equipment The number of people on the estate with no formal educational qualification is high and so our staff and volunteers are able to help and encourage the children to aspire and do well at school. They will sometimes bring homework for staff to look at. We have a good selection of books they can refer to and they quite often can be seen playing schools or offices. The Constitution of Blackbird Leys Adventure Playground states: "The objects of BLAP shall be the provision of play and recreation facilities and other leisure time occupation for children resident in and around Oxford...the facilities being a) those of which children have need by reason of their youth or social and economic circumstances and b) Those which will improve the conditions of life for such children by promoting their physical, mental and spiritual well-being."
recipientOrganization.name: Blackbird Leys Adventure Playground

FAO aims to introduce contemporary folk arts to both established and new audiences - including those who face barriers to participation - and to foster and promote the many forms of traditional performing arts. Our main ongoing projects are the Folk Weekend festival held in April, and the FolkinOxford.co.uk web resource. We also run short-term projects, such as our current Heritage Lottery funded project. Alongside our own projects and events, we work collaboratively with other local organisations, creating opportunities for folk artists to work in education and community projects as well as showcase their talent in local events. recipientOrganization.description: Aims: 1 . To encourage and support local people to come together in order to enhance their social interaction and caring networks. 2. To maintain and develop partnerships with local people, voluntary and statutory agencies and funding bodies to work together to tackle local concerns and needs. 3. To maintain a safe, secure and inclusive community centre and professional standard of service for staff, volunteers, local residents and all visitors to the centre. 4. To raise the profile of Cutteslowe, in order to encourage participation and to attract more activities, services and resources to the local area. We meet these aims by means of a committee structure with 8 active trustees. We have a number of groups meeting regularly in the centre including: 4 youth clubs, 3 after school weekly clubs, an allotment club, a fortnightly seniors club, a monthly community lunch, a summer playscheme, bingo nights. The centre is let out to local organisations which provides an income stream.
recipientOrganization.name: Cutteslowe Community Association

recipientOrganization.description: Deddington OnAir is a not-for-profit charity limited by guarantee that aims to provide an internet radio service for Deddington, Hempton, Clifton and the surround villages of North Oxfordshire. The station aims to involve all elements of the community especially the youth and elderly in a project that will benefit everyone, enhance community cohesion and provide an interest and activity for all. We also provide work experience placements to local schools, assistance in getting clubs and societies to publicise and promote themselves through radio and to offer a creative outlet to all. This year we offered 5 work experience placements and wish to continue this through this funding application. Please visit the website to see this in action.

recipientOrganization.description: Bicester Green is an independent, not for profit social enterprise, led by the local community, and delivered in partnership with other organisations. We are are aiming to become a one-stop shop for all matters to do with sustainability and re-use. Our main activities are repair and refurbishment of items, such as small electricals, wooden furniture, and bicycles. There is also a programme of educational activities, and support provided to other community organisations. Bicester Green won the OCVA Environmental Award in February 2015, sponsored by the Oxford Bus Company.

recipientOrganization.description: We work with patients of oesophageal or stomach cancer, and their families, to help them understand better the pathway they will be taking and how best they need to change their lifestyle. The support we provide includes counselling, practical advice, education and information not normally provided by the statutory authorities. We do not provide medical advice but focus on practical advice from a patient's viewpoint. We provide a telephone support line which is manned well beyond normal office hours. We facilitate meetings between patients and their carers, family and friends with members of the clinical team involved in their treatment. We represent the patient voice on medical committees and similar forums. Generally we stay in touch with the patient and their family for 9 months to a year. OOSO has the unreserved backing of the patients, nurses and doctors of the Upper GI service in Oxford (Churchill Hospital).
recipientOrganization.name: Oxfordshire Oesophageal and Stomach Organisation (OOSO)

recipientOrganization.description: The Thomas Gifford Trust has existed since 1592, and its members work to "promote such charitable purposes in the Charlbury area for the benefit of its inhabitants as the Trustees shall think fit, and to maintain the Charlbury Playing Close for the benefit of the inhabitants of the area". As well as the Playing Close, The Thomas Gifford Trust owns some land in the Spendlove Centre (the site of the old Spendlove Secondary School) in the middle of Charlbury. This site is adjacent to the Co-operative store, doctor's and dentist's surgeries, and other commercial enterprises and it butts onto the playing fields which contain football and rugby pitches, tennis courts and a children's playground. This land has been vacant since the demolition of the school and is the location of our proposed Community Centre, which will bring much needed sports and leisure facilities to Charlbury. The construction of this new Community Centre, which will begin in 2015, will comprise of many state of the art facilities. There will be a four badminton court sized sports hall, a contemporary library, a dance/yoga studio and social areas.The Thomas Gifford Trust together with the Charlbury Community Centre Appeal Committee has been raising funds to build this Community Centre for over 10 years. We have been awarded financial support from: Oxfordshire County Council, Charlbury Town Council, West Oxfordshire District Council, Homes and Communities Agency, Charlbury Motor and Fire Brigade Fund, private donations and local residents through the Charlbury Community Centre Appeal Fund. We are now in a position to start building, but need to raise more money for internal fixtures and fittings and to make the building as useful and attractive to as many people as possible in the town and surrounding villages.
recipientOrganization.name: Thomas Giffords Charity

recipientOrganization.description: Employment Action Group grew from the needs of the locality in 1983. Our objective is to help anyone disadvantaged in the labour market. Berinsfield is a disadvantaged area with surprisingly low educational attainment, low self-esteem and low aspiration. We engage through community activities (sewing group, furniture re-cycling project, table tennis); and we aim to raise aspiration, and create employment and learning opportunities. Our Apprenticeship Programme, run in partnership with a local business, targets disengaged students (Years 10 -11) in local schools, before they become disaffected. We have recently recruited a Business Engagement Lead to develop the programme and encourage other local businesses to participate. Our Enterprise Centre encourages employment and business into Berinsfield.
recipientOrganization.name: Employment Action Group (Berinsfield) Ltd

recipientOrganization.description: The Story Museum is a pioneering education charity established in Oxford in 2003. Our purpose is to inspire learning through story. We believe that stories are not just important for children’s learning and development; they are a fundamental part of what it means to be human. To that end we are gradually transforming our site in central Oxford (thanks to an Arts Council Small capital grant and other support from Trusts and Foundations) into a new kind of museum — the first of its kind — celebrating story in all its forms and acting as a hub for our education and engagement work. Since 2005 we have been running storytelling programmes in schools and communities across Oxfordshire that show the power of stories to inspire and transform learning. Our work has particularly targeted some of the most disadvantaged areas of the county and we work in partnership with a wide variety of communities and other like-minded organisations.
recipientOrganization.name: Story Museum

recipientOrganization.description: Oxford Hub is a student-led network with a membership of over 6,500 students and 35 student societies and volunteering projects at the University of Oxford. We believe that university students have the power and potential to shape a better world. We know that the current challenges faced by local and global communities – from climate change to educational disadvantage to an ageing population – can only be solved by engaging the students of today, the leaders of tomorrow, with these pressing social issues and equipping them with the skills to solve them. We: - inspire students about social issues each year through conferences and speaker events on social issues; - connect students to opportunities to make a difference in their local communities - in local schools, care homes and food banks; - support students to set up their own charitable projects through our social leadership activities. Oxford Hub is part of Student Hubs, a national charity.
recipientOrganization.name: Hub Ventures

recipientOrganization.description: “Yellow Submarine Holidays” provides supported holidays and activities for people with learning disabilities (PWLD). It operates with three aims: 1/ to offer PWLD choice in holiday options and day-trips at affordable (/subsidised) prices; 2/ to provide respite for those who care for PWLD; 3/ to give young people training and volunteering opportunities to support this vulnerable group on our outings both for the immediate gain of assisting positively and so they are better equipped to promote community cohesion. In 2009, Yellow Submarine partnered with two day centres and a local authority and four holidays with 19 PWLD (and their carers who gained respite) benefitting. The trips that have taken place so far have been very popular and successful both with the ‘service users’, their carers and the volunteers who helped. Video feedback can be viewed on our site, with carers saying the holidays have helped increase confidence, create new friendships, and give a welcome break! Yellow Submarine believes people with learning disabilities deserve to live life to the full. We are a small award-winning charity which prides itself on giving some of the most disadvantaged people in Oxfordshire confidence, independence and a sense of self-worth. For children (aged 11-18) living in Oxfordshire we run an extensive programme in the school holidays. For adults (18+) we run residential holidays, work experience & training and a weekly social club. Case study published on website Nov 2014, original stored here: Y:\NEW FILESTORE 2011\7 MARKETING, COMMS & CAMPAIGNS\CASE STUDIES\Grant stories
recipientOrganization.name: Yellow Submarine

recipientOrganization.description: We aim to help visually impaired persons in Oxfordshire in as personal and professional a way as possible. We provide: An advice and information service with the range of equipment and visual aids that is available to help visually impaired people, like talking clocks or compter-based reading equipment. Two volunteer home visiting schemes, for visually impaired people in Oxford and Banbury. A telephone counselling service for blind or partially sighted people who are struggling to come to terms with the loss of their vision. Providing a Sight Advice Desk at the Eye Clinic of the John Radcliffe Hospital. Managing or supporting the local meeting groups and societies for visually impaired people like VIBNO.

recipientOrganization.description: BLNSS Ltd. runs the Agnes Smith Advice Centre, which provides information and advice to the residents of Blackbird Leys and surrounding areas, in particular on welfare benefits and debt issues. We provide free, independent, impartial and confidential advice, helping to maximise income, establish plans to tackle debt, enable people to remain living in their own homes and empower people to have more control in their lives. We ask other charities for help with emergency grants. A solicitor visits fortnightly to take up legal cases where necessary. We are firmly rooted in the local community and enjoy good relationships with a range of local bodies. Our work brings in additional income to the local community through benefit take-up and debt write-off. We also train and support local volunteers to play a key role in the centre and acquire skills that will help them move on to training or employment opportuntities, or take up the chance to train as a volunteer advice worker with us.
recipientOrganization.name: Blackbird Leys Neighbourhood Support Scheme Ltd

recipientOrganization.description: OSARCC aims to provide specialist support to women and girls in Oxfordshire who have experienced rape and/or sexual abuse, either recently or in the past, and to raise public awareness on issues related to sexual violence. Our Centre is community-based and independent; run for women, by women. We meet a need for accessible, high-quality and specialised support. Services include a telephone helpline and email support service. We also support those who are supporting survivors. In 2011 we launched a Support Group service and this year we are launching an external training service for professionals working with survivors. Services are delivered by a team of volunteers who complete OSARCC's comprehensive training programme. They have frequently been affected by the issues themselves, either directly as survivors or indirectly via family or friends. We are a member of Rape Crisis England and Wales, and are working towards their National Service Standards.
recipientOrganization.name: Oxford Sexual Abuse & Rape Crisis Centre
